title: Malati Shendge
text:
Malati J. Shendge (1934–2015) was an <a href="Indologist">Indologist</a>. She received her Ph.D in Buddhism from the <a href="University%20of%20Delhi">University of Delhi</a>. She had been a fellow of the <a href="Indian%20Council%20of%20Historical%20Research">Indian Council of Historical Research</a>, and of the <a href="Indian%20Institute%20of%20Advanced%20Study">Indian Institute of Advanced Study</a>, Shimla. She was a faculty member at <a href="Jawaharlal%20Nehru%20University%2C%20Delhi">Jawaharlal Nehru University</a>, and Founder Director (Hon.) of the Rang Datta Wadekar Centre for the study of Indian Tradition, Pune.
Theories.
Shendge has written a number of books on the connections between the <a href="Indus%20Valley%20Civilization">Indus Valley Civilization</a> and <a href="Vedic%20culture">Vedic culture</a>. Her early work, "The Civilized Demons", reinterprets the heavenly battle between the <a href="Asura">Asura</a>s and the Devas described in the <a href="Rigveda">Rigveda</a> as a historical record of an earthly war in the <a href="Indus%20Valley">Indus Valley</a> between the Asuras (identified by her as being the <a href="Assyrian%20people">Assyrian people</a>) already living in the valley as the <a href="Indus%20Valley%20Civilisation">Harappan Civilization</a>, and the invading Devas (identified by her with the <a href="Aryan">Aryan</a>s). Her 1997 book "The Language of the Harappans" extends this theory by claiming that the unknown <a href="Harappan%20language">Harappan language</a> was the <a href="Akkadian%20language">Akkadian language</a> of <a href="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, and that <a href="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> is a descendant of Akkadian. In "Unsealing the Indus Script" (2009) she purports to decode the <a href="Indus%20script">Indus script</a> based on this theory.
